results_summary: Fish oil moderately increased circulating adiponectin by 0.37 μg/mL, though with unexplained heterogeneity and potential publication bias. Fish feeding did not show a statistically significant effect on adiponectin levels.
population_specificity: Humans in randomized, placebo-controlled clinical trials.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil (LCn-3PUFA) combined with a reduced-energy diet facilitated weight loss and improved blood lipids and inflammatory mediators.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation did not significantly enhance weight loss or fat mass reduction compared to placebo, though it increased plasma EPA and DHA levels and reduced triglycerides by 27%. No significant changes were observed in other inflammatory biomarkers or blood lipids.
population_specificity: Adults following a low-energy diet (placebo group n=18, fish oil group n=17).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how dietary n3 PUFAs from fish interact with adiponectin gene polymorphisms to influence serum adiponectin concentrations.
results_summary: The study found that the -11391 A-allele was associated with higher baseline adiponectin levels, and individuals homozygous for the +45 T-allele aged >58 years showed a 22% increase in adiponectin after the highest n3 PUFA dose. The interaction between treatment, age, and genotype was significant, suggesting potential benefits for older individuals with specific genetic profiles.
population_specificity: 142 healthy men and 225 women aged 45-70 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether fish oil supplementation affects appetite in healthy individuals.
results_summary: The study found no difference in pre-breakfast appetite scores between fish oil and soybean oil, but post-prandial fullness was slightly lower after fish oil. A gender-specific effect was observed, with women showing an increased "desire to eat more" after fish oil supplementation.
population_specificity: 20 normal-weight subjects (50% females).
study_duration: 3 weeks per intervention, separated by a 1-week wash-out.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the associations between immune response changes (specifically interleukin-10 and tumor necrosis factor-α levels) and preterm delivery, omega-3 supplementation, and fish diet in women with prior spontaneous preterm birth.
results_summary: The study found no significant effect of omega-3 supplementation or fish diet on changes in interleukin-10 or tumor necrosis factor-α levels. Preterm birth was associated with decreased interleukin-10 production, but fish diet did not influence these outcomes.
population_specificity: Women with prior spontaneous preterm birth, assessed at 16-22 weeks and 25-28 weeks of gestation.
study_duration: Intervention duration not explicitly stated, but measurements were taken at two time points (16-22 weeks and 25-28 weeks of gestation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of dietary supplementation, including fish oil, on the quality of life of retired football players.
results_summary: The study found improvements in general health, mental health days, health satisfaction, physical and psychological domains, memory, vigor, and reduced pain in specific joints. No adverse events were reported.
population_specificity: Retired professional football players (n=15).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of fish oil supplementation on heart rate variability in humans through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation did not significantly affect time-domain parameters of heart rate variability but increased high-frequency power (vagal tone) and showed a trend toward reducing the LF/HF ratio, suggesting potential antiarrhythmic benefits.
population_specificity: Humans (participants in randomized controlled trials)
effective_dosage: Dose <1000 mg/d in 2 studies; other dosages not specified

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation affects neural cardiovascular reactivity to mental stress, specifically examining blood pressure, heart rate, muscle sympathetic nerve activity, and vascular conductance responses.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation for 8 weeks blunted heart rate and total muscle sympathetic nerve activity reactivity to mental stress, as well as calf vascular conductance, but did not significantly alter blood pressure or forearm vascular conductance responses.
population_specificity: 67 nonhypertensive subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with LCω-3PUFA (fish oil) alone and in combination with a very low energy diet (VLED) facilitated weight loss, improved blood lipids, and positively affected inflammatory mediators.
results_summary: The study found that fish oil supplementation increased EPA and DHA levels but did not significantly affect anthropometric measurements initially. However, after 8 weeks, females in the fish oil group showed a greater percentage reduction in weight and BMI compared to the placebo group.
population_specificity: Adults (n = 39, 19 placebo, 20 fish oil) with a focus on gender-specific effects.
effective_dosage: 6 × 1 g capsules per day (70 mg EPA and 270 mg DHA per capsule).
study_duration: 8 weeks (4 weeks supplementation alone, 4 weeks with VLED).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased intake of n-3 PUFAs and oily fish during pregnancy and infancy reduces the incidence of allergy-related diseases, particularly asthma, at 2 years of age.
results_summary: Increased intake of n-3 PUFAs and oily fish was associated with reduced asthma incidence (OR 0.72) and asthma medication use (OR 0.75), with a stronger effect in girls (OR 0.41) than boys (OR 0.93). No significant changes were observed for wheeze or atopic dermatitis.
population_specificity: Non-selected population of mothers and their infants followed from pregnancy to 2 years of age.
study_duration: Pregnancy and the first 2 years of life

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the metabolic and anti-inflammatory effects of two different doses of fish oil (ω-3 PUFAs) on adipose tissue in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that 3.6 g/d of ω-3 PUFA improved lipid profiles and upregulated adipokine gene expression, while 1.8 g/d reduced inflammation-related gene expression in adipose tissue. No significant changes were observed in body weight, glucose, insulin, or inflammatory markers like adiponectin and leptin.
population_specificity: Non-dialyzed patients with stage IV/V CKD (n=12).
effective_dosage: 1.8 g/d or 3.6 g/d of ω-3 PUFA.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether maternal omega-3 LCPUFA supplementation during pregnancy improves neurologic and visual development in offspring.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in cognitive, language, or motor development between supplemented and control groups, except for a modest improvement in cognitive scores in 2-5-year-old children from two trials with high bias risk. Visual outcomes were inconclusive due to varied assessments.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding ω-3 PUFAs (from fish oil) to parenteral nutrition could reduce inflammation and improve immune function in patients after esophageal cancer surgery.
results_summary: The study found that ω-3 PUFAs supplementation significantly reduced serum procalcitonin levels and increased the CD4(+)/CD8(+) ratio by postoperative day 6, indicating reduced inflammation and improved immune function. No significant effects were observed on postoperative days 1 and 3.
population_specificity: 60 patients with esophageal cancer and nutritional risk (NRS2002 score ≥3).
study_duration: Measurements taken intraoperatively and at 24, 72, and 144 hours postoperatively.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the environmental and dietary factors affecting vitamin D health, including the role of fish-derived sources like cod liver oil in preventing bone diseases.
results_summary: The study highlights that fish, particularly cod liver oil, was historically used to prevent rickets and osteomalacia, but notes that many edible fish species are now threatened. It suggests vitamin D supplementation as an alternative due to ecosystem degradation and population pressures.
population_specificity: General population, with specific mention of children and aging adults in North-East Asia.

study_goal: To investigate the effects of DHA-rich fish oil supplementation on lymphocyte function before and after a marathon race.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation increased lymphocyte proliferation and prevented a decrease in cytokine production but did not prevent lymphocyte death induced by marathon participation. The marathon itself increased cell death markers and reduced cytokine production in the control group.
population_specificity: 21 athletes (8 supplemented with fish oil, 13 controls).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3 PUFA supplementation from fish could reduce urine albumin excretion and markers of kidney injury in adults with type 2 diabetes and early kidney disease.
results_summary: The study found that n-3 PUFA supplementation had a nonsignificant effect on urine albumin excretion but significantly reduced urine NGAL excretion. Subgroup analyses showed significant decreases in kidney injury markers among participants taking RAAS-blocking medications.
population_specificity: Adults with type 2 diabetes and ≥ trace proteinuria (mean age 67, 55% male, 61% African American).
study_duration: Two 6-week periods separated by a 2-week washout
interactions: Enhanced effects observed in participants taking RAAS-blocking medications.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether early omega-3 LC-PUFA supplementation improves intestinal integrity, growth, and cognitive function in Gambian infants.
results_summary: Supplementation increased plasma n-3 LC-PUFA concentrations and midupper arm circumference but did not improve linear growth, intestinal integrity, morbidity, or selected cognitive measures.
population_specificity: 172 rural Gambian infants aged 3-9 months.
effective_dosage: 200 mg DHA and 300 mg EPA daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the joint effect of multiple beneficial dietary components, including fish oil, on asthma outcomes in children.
results_summary: The study found that the supplement group (including fish oil) showed significant improvement in pulmonary function parameters and reduced medication usage compared to the placebo group, though quality of life and asthma control scores did not differ significantly.
population_specificity: Asthmatic children aged 10-12 years from elementary schools in metropolitan Taipei.
effective_dosage: Not specified (combined with fruit, vegetable concentrate, and probiotics as FVFP supplement).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of consuming fish versus fish oil supplements on plasma total and HMW adiponectin concentrations in overweight and obese participants.
results_summary: Fish consumption increased HMW adiponectin levels, while fish oil supplements decreased them. No significant changes were observed in other anthropometric or biochemical variables.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese human participants
effective_dosage: 1.8 g of long-chain omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (LC n-3 PUFA) daily

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of five weeks of long-chain n-3 PUFA intake on cognitive performance in healthy individuals and explore its relation to cardiometabolic risk parameters.
results_summary: Supplementation with n-3 PUFA improved working memory performance, lowered plasma triacylglycerides, and reduced systolic blood pressure. Inverse relationships were found between cardiometabolic risk factors (blood pressure, glucose, TNF-α) and cognitive performance.
population_specificity: 40 healthy middle-aged to elderly subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to clarify associations between fish consumption, long-chain omega-3 fatty acids, and cerebrovascular disease risk in primary and secondary prevention.
results_summary: Moderate fish consumption (2-4 servings/week) was associated with a reduced risk of cerebrovascular disease, while omega-3 supplements showed no significant association. The benefits of fish intake likely stem from a combination of nutrients rather than omega-3 alone.
population_specificity: Participants with or without baseline cardiovascular disease (primary and secondary prevention).
effective_dosage: 2-4 servings/week and ≥5 servings/week compared to ≤1 serving/week.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3PUFA supplementation (1 g/day) improves cardiac autonomic control in patients with heart failure.
results_summary: n-3PUFA supplementation partially restored autonomic modulation in chronic HF patients, with significant improvements in heart rate variability and turbulence slope after 3 months, though effects diminished by 12 months.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure of any cause and severity (82% men, 36% >70 years, 92% with left ventricular ejection fraction <40%, 80% in NYHA class II).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative supplementation with n-3-PUFAs (fish oil) reduces the risk of postoperative atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients undergoing cardiac surgery.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the occurrence of postoperative AF between the fish oil and placebo groups, with both showing similar rates of AF episodes and no reduction in secondary endpoints. Fish oil supplementation was well-tolerated with no increased risk of bleeding or serious adverse events.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled for cardiac surgery in 28 centers across the United States, Italy, and Argentina, with a mean age of 64 years and 72.2% male.
effective_dosage: Preoperative loading of 10 g over 3-5 days (or 8 g over 2 days), followed by 2 g/day postoperatively until hospital discharge or postoperative day 10.
study_duration: Variable, depending on hospital discharge or up to 10 days post-surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of fish oil supplementation on appetite, caloric intake, body weight, and lean body mass in children with leukemia.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly improved mid upper arm muscle circumference (MUAMC), appetite level, and showed an increasing trend in energy and protein intake compared to the control group. The trial group demonstrated better outcomes in MUAMC (0.13 cm vs -0.09 cm) and appetite (0.12±0.33) at 8 weeks.
population_specificity: 51 children with leukemia aged 4 to 12 years.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether omega-3 fatty acids (fish oil) supplementation after a traumatic event could prevent PTSD and explore its underlying mechanisms.
results_summary: The study found that one of eight patients developed PTSD, showing large reactivity to startle tones but not to trauma-related cues. The combination of psychophysiological measurements suggested potential insights into omega-3's preventive mechanisms.
population_specificity: 8 patients who experienced a traumatic event.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of fish oil supplementation on circulating levels of inflammatory markers in patients with chronic heart failure.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly reduced circulating levels of tumor necrosis factor α, interleukin 1, and interleukin 6, but did not significantly affect high sensitivity C-reactive protein, soluble intracellular adhesion molecular 1, or vascular cell adhesion molecular 1. Greater reductions in inflammatory markers were observed with higher doses (over 1000 mg/day) or longer durations (over 4 months) of supplementation.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure
effective_dosage: Over 1000 mg/day (higher dose associated with greater effects)
study_duration: Over 4 months (longer duration associated with greater effects)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of a prebiotic mixture (scGOS/lcFOS/pAOS) on the faecal microbiota and microenvironment in preterm infants, as well as the influence of perinatal factors on microbiota development.
results_summary: The prebiotic mixture increased total bacteria count at day 14 and decreased faecal pH, with a trend toward increased bifidobacteria and acetic acid. However, broad-spectrum antibiotics significantly reduced total bacteria count, delaying normal microbiota development.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with gestational age <32 weeks and/or birth weight <1,500 g.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of fish oil supplementation on maternal and fetal fatty acid profiles and identify the best compartment for assessing fatty acid status.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation increased DHA levels in maternal and cord plasma and erythrocyte phospholipids, with higher percentage changes observed in erythrocytes. Significant correlations between maternal and cord fatty acid levels were found, with erythrocytes appearing more reliable for neonates.
population_specificity: Healthy pregnant women from three European centers.
study_duration: From week 20 of gestation until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of fish oil supplements on HDL-C, Apo-AI, MDA, Aryl, and PON1 activity in female rheumatoid arthritis patients.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly increased HDL-C, Aryl, and PON1 activity while decreasing MDA levels. Correlations were found between increased PON1 activity and HDL-C/Apo-AI concentrations.
population_specificity: Female patients with rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether nonfish sources of omega-3 PUFA are as effective as fatty fish-derived omega-3 PUFA in managing cardiovascular disease (CVD) risk factors.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 PUFA from fatty fish has cardioprotective effects, including hypolipemic, anti-inflammatory, and anti-arrhythmic properties, but nonfish sources vary in their ability to regulate blood levels of omega-3 PUFA and CVD risk factors.
population_specificity: Greenland Inuits (epidemiological studies) and subsequent human studies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify the percentage of patients in a cardiac rehabilitation program taking fish oil/omega-3 supplements.
results_summary: The study found that 27% of patients in the program were taking fish oil/omega-3 supplements, making it the second most common supplement after multivitamins. No specific efficacy or safety outcomes related to fish oil were reported.
population_specificity: Patients enrolled in a phase 3 cardiac rehabilitation program (n=235).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of fish oil on cardiac function, ventricular remodeling, and functional capacity in patients with chronic heart failure (CHF).
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly improved left ventricular ejection fraction and reduced left ventricular end-systolic volume in CHF patients, particularly those with non-ischaemic heart failure. It also improved functional classification and peak oxygen consumption in non-ischaemic heart failure patients.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic heart failure (CHF), with notable effects in non-ischaemic heart failure subgroups.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether increased salmon consumption during pregnancy alters breast milk fatty acid composition and immune factors.
results_summary: Breast milk from the salmon group had significantly higher proportions of EPA, docosapentaenoic acid, and DHA compared to controls, while the LC (n-6) PUFA:LC (n-3) PUFA ratio was lower. However, breast milk secretory IgA was lower in the salmon group, though the implications of this are unclear.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (n = 123) who rarely ate oily fish.
effective_dosage: 2 portions of farmed salmon per week, providing 3.45 g long-chain (n-3) PUFA per week.
study_duration: From 20 weeks of pregnancy until delivery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of n-3 LCPUFA intake during pregnancy on maternal and child health outcomes, including birthweight and preterm delivery.
results_summary: n-3 LCPUFA supplementation during pregnancy modestly increased birthweight and reduced the risk of early preterm delivery, but showed no significant effects on birth length, head circumference, pre-eclampsia, or infant mortality. Observational studies reported mixed findings on fish intake and birth outcomes.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (studied across 15 randomized controlled trials and 14 observational studies).
study_duration: At least one trimester of pregnancy

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the current literature on the use of Omega-3 fatty acids for treating coronary artery disease (CAD) and discuss potential benefits.
results_summary: Omega-3 PUFAs were found to reduce the risk of cardiovascular disease, including fatal and non-fatal myocardial infarction, stroke, CAD, sudden cardiac death, and all-cause mortality, with minimal adverse effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cardiovascular disease risk population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether n-3 LCP supplementation from fish or other sources prevents or improves cognitive decline in older adults, including those with pre-existing cognitive impairment or dementia.
results_summary: The study found no evidence supporting the routine use of n-3 LCP supplements for preventing or ameliorating cognitive decline in later life, despite observational and mechanistic data suggesting potential benefits. The findings were consistent across trials involving both cognitively healthy older individuals and those with pre-existing cognitive decline or dementia.
population_specificity: Cognitively healthy older people and individuals with pre-existing cognitive decline or dementia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess whether omega-3 PUFA supplementation prevents dementia and cognitive decline in cognitively healthy older adults.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit of omega-3 PUFA supplementation on cognitive function in healthy older adults, with no difference in cognitive test scores between intervention and placebo groups. Mild gastrointestinal issues were the most common side effect, reported by fewer than 15% of participants.
population_specificity: Cognitively healthy adults aged 60 years and older.
effective_dosage: Not specified (gel capsules or margarine spread containing omega-3 PUFA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the effectiveness of omega-3 PUFA (from fish oil) as a therapeutic agent for inflammatory bowel disease (both active and inactive ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease).
results_summary: The review found insufficient evidence to support the use of omega-3 PUFA supplementation for treating inflammatory bowel disease, with consistent negative results for maintaining remission (especially in ulcerative colitis). Trials on active disease were inconclusive due to design heterogeneity or limited numbers.
population_specificity: Patients with active or inactive ulcerative colitis or Crohn's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation improves endothelial function, as measured by flow-mediated dilation in humans.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that fish oil supplementation significantly improved flow-mediated dilation overall, but this effect was mainly driven by lower-quality studies. High-quality, double-blind, placebo-controlled studies showed no significant effect.
population_specificity: 1,385 subjects, including normoglycemic individuals and those with lower diastolic blood pressure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3 LCPUFA (DHA) supplementation during pregnancy reduces the incidence of gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) or preeclampsia, and its effect on perinatal complications.
results_summary: The study found no significant reduction in GDM or preeclampsia with DHA supplementation. However, fewer perinatal deaths and neonatal convulsions were observed in the DHA group, though further investigation is needed.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (<21 weeks gestation)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation could protect against adverse cardiac and lipid effects caused by exposure to air pollution.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation attenuated air pollution-induced reductions in heart rate variability ratios and prevented increases in low-frequency HRV and QTc prolongation. It also prevented the rise in very low-density lipoprotein and triglycerides observed in the olive oil group.
population_specificity: Healthy middle-aged adults (mean age 58 ± 1 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation could improve synthetic hemodialysis graft patency and reduce cardiovascular events in patients with stage 5 chronic kidney disease.
results_summary: Fish oil did not significantly reduce the proportion of grafts losing native patency but improved secondary outcomes, including lower graft failure rates, fewer thromboses, fewer corrective interventions, and better cardiovascular event-free survival. However, the primary outcome did not show a statistically significant difference.
population_specificity: Adults with stage 5 chronic kidney disease (50% women, 63% white, 53% with diabetes) undergoing hemodialysis with synthetic arteriovenous grafts.
effective_dosage: Four 1-g fish oil capsules per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation during the third trimester of pregnancy affects blood pressure, heart rate, and heart rate variability in the offspring at 19 years of age.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in blood pressure, heart rate, or heart rate variability between offspring whose mothers received fish oil versus olive oil during pregnancy. The effects of fish oil supplementation were minimal and not clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Pregnant women during their third trimester and their 19-year-old offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of SDA-enhanced soybean oil as a sustainable alternative to fish-derived omega-3 fatty acids for improving cardiovascular health.
results_summary: The study found that SDA-enhanced soybean oil significantly improved the omega-3 index (RBC EPA+DHA), suggesting potential cardiovascular benefits, including reduced risk for sudden cardiac death and slower cellular aging. The results align with benefits observed in prior studies using EPA supplementation.
population_specificity: Not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of omega-3 fatty acids (EPA+DHA) from fish oil in preventing sudden death in acute coronary syndrome and reducing hospital admissions for cardiovascular events in chronic heart failure patients.
results_summary: The study found that 1 g/day of omega-3 (EPA+DHA) from fish oil can prevent sudden death in acute coronary syndrome and reduce hospital admissions for cardiovascular events in chronic heart failure patients. It also highlighted glutamine as a major energy source for myocytes, offering protection against ischemia.
population_specificity: Patients with cardiac disease, including those with acute coronary syndrome and chronic heart failure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether acute and short-term supplementation with a low dose of marine n-3 PUFA from fish oil exerts an anti-inflammatory effect in overweight subjects.
results_summary: After 6 weeks, fish oil supplementation significantly increased n-3 PUFA content in granulocytes and adipose tissue and slightly raised serum adiponectin levels, but no overall anti-inflammatory effect was demonstrated. No significant effects were observed after 1 day of supplementation.
population_specificity: Overweight subjects (n=50)
effective_dosage: 2 g of fish oil daily (containing 1.1 g marine n-3 PUFA)

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine whether dietary ω-3 fatty acid supplementation during early childhood prevents the association between impaired fetal growth and carotid arterial wall thickening.
results_summary: In the control group, fetal growth was inversely associated with carotid intima-media thickness (IMT), but this association was prevented in the ω-3 group, indicating that ω-3 supplementation over the first 5 years of life can mitigate arterial wall thickening linked to impaired fetal growth.
population_specificity: 616 children born at term, recruited antenatally from maternity hospitals in Sydney, with a focus on those with birth weight <90th percentile (ω-3 group [n = 187], control group [n = 176]).
effective_dosage: 500 mg daily fish oil supplement, along with canola-based margarines and cooking oil.
study_duration: From the start of bottle-feeding or 6 months of age until 5 years of age.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of ω-3 fatty acids from fish oil on immune and inflammatory modulation in surgical intensive care unit (SICU) patients.
results_summary: The study found that fish oil supplementation reduced inflammatory cytokines (IL-1, IL-8, IFN-γ, IL-6, and TNF-α) and showed trends toward reduced liver dysfunction and infection rates, though these were not statistically significant. Both lipid regimens were well tolerated with no mortality reported.
population_specificity: SICU patients admitted after major surgery (n=38).
effective_dosage: Not specified (part of lipid replaced by fish oil in PN).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of high-dose fish oil supplementation on infant neurodevelopmental outcomes and language.
results_summary: The study found no significant benefit to global infant neurodevelopment from high-dose fish oil supplementation, but observed some improvements in early communicative development, such as higher percentile ranks of later developing gestures and total number of gestures.
population_specificity: 420 healthy term infants.
effective_dosage: At least 250 mg DHA/day and 60 mg EPA/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the chronic effects of fish oil supplementation combined with strength training on muscle strength and functional capacity in older women.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation enhanced the benefits of strength training, leading to greater improvements in muscle strength, functional capacity, and neuromuscular performance compared to strength training alone. The effects were more pronounced in groups receiving fish oil for longer durations.
population_specificity: Older women (aged 64 ± 1.4 years)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether creatine supplementation could reduce oxidative stress and DNA damage induced by resistance exercise in male athletes.
results_summary: Creatine supplementation significantly improved athletic performance and reduced oxidative DNA damage (measured by urinary 8-OHdG) and lipid peroxidation (measured by plasma MDA) following resistance exercise.
population_specificity: 27 resistance-trained male athletes (ages 21.2 ± 3.2 to 21.6 ± 3.6 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of fish-oil containing feeds in improving outcomes for trauma patients, particularly those with ARDS.
results_summary: Fish-oil containing feeds showed some promise but were recommended to be reserved for specific subgroups of patients with ARDS, indicating limited but potential efficacy.
population_specificity: Military trauma patients and critically ill patients, particularly those with ARDS.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of dietary nutrients, including DHA from fish, in cognitive aging and dementia.
results_summary: The study found strong protective associations for DHA, an n-3 fatty acid found in fish, in relation to cognitive aging and dementia. Evidence from epidemiological studies and clinical trials supports its efficacy, though inconsistencies exist due to varying nutrient intake levels.
population_specificity: General population with a focus on cognitive aging and dementia risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether long-chain n-3 PUFA (fish oil) combined with a very-low-energy diet (VLED) improved weight loss, weight maintenance, blood lipids, and inflammatory mediators compared to a placebo.
results_summary: The study found that fish oil supplementation led to a significant increase in plasma EPA and DHA levels but did not significantly enhance weight loss or maintenance compared to the placebo. However, the fish oil group showed a significant reduction in fat mass after 14 weeks, while metabolic profiles improved in both groups.
population_specificity: Adults on a very-low-energy diet (VLED) for weight loss and maintenance.
effective_dosage: 6 × 1 g capsules/day (70 mg EPA and 270 mg DHA per capsule).
study_duration: 14 weeks (4 weeks VLED, 10 weeks weight maintenance).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effect of fish oil supplementation during pregnancy on infants' development at 10 months.
results_summary: The study found no effect of fish oil supplementation on infants' development. Low-birth-weight infants scored significantly lower on mental and psychomotor development indices compared to normal-birth-weight infants.
population_specificity: Pregnant women and their infants in a poor-urban Bangladeshi community.
study_duration: Duration of pregnancy (exact length not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of DHA-rich and EPA-rich fish oil supplementation on cerebral hemodynamics and cognitive task performance in healthy adults.
results_summary: DHA-rich fish oil significantly increased cerebral blood flow (measured via oxy-Hb and total Hb levels) during cognitive tasks, while EPA-rich fish oil showed no effect compared to placebo. The study suggests DHA may enhance brain function by improving blood flow.
population_specificity: Twenty-two healthy adults.
effective_dosage: 1 g daily of either DHA-rich fish oil, EPA-rich fish oil, or placebo (olive oil).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to quantify the effects of n-3 supplementation on arterial stiffness, a risk factor for cardiovascular disease, through meta-analysis.
results_summary: The meta-analysis found that n-3 supplementation significantly improved both pulse wave velocity and arterial compliance, with no evidence of heterogeneity or publication bias. The results were not influenced by changes in blood pressure, heart rate, or BMI, suggesting n-3 effectively reduces arterial stiffness.
population_specificity: Adult human participants in randomized and controlled clinical trials.
effective_dosage: Not specified (no limits were set on dosage sizes).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with fish-derived EPA and DHA, plant-derived ALA, or a combination of both could improve affective states (depressive symptoms and dispositional optimism) in post-MI patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in depressive symptoms or dispositional optimism between groups receiving EPA-DHA, ALA, or a combination compared to placebo after 40 months of supplementation. Plasma concentrations of the fatty acids increased, but these changes did not translate to measurable psychological benefits.
population_specificity: Post-myocardial infarction patients aged 60-80 years (79.2% men).
effective_dosage: 400 mg EPA-DHA per day, 2 g ALA per day, or both.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the changes in LDL particle subclasses and phenotype patterns in hypertriglyceridemic adults after fish oil supplementation.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation significantly reduced triglyceride levels and modestly increased LDL-C, with increases distributed across smaller and larger LDL particles. Changes in LDL phenotype patterns were negligible.
population_specificity: Hypertriglyceridemic adults

study_goal: To investigate gene expression changes in PBMCs following n-3 PUFA and n-3 PUFA+FG supplementation in obese insulin-resistant subjects.
results_summary: Both supplementations increased erythrocyte n-3 PUFA concentration and reduced plasma triglycerides without altering inflammatory parameters. Gene expression changes differed between the two supplementations, but metabolic pathway impacts were comparable.
population_specificity: 16 obese insulin-resistant subjects

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether n-3 fatty acid (fish oil) supplementation during the third trimester of pregnancy affects lipid profiles in the offspring by adolescence.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in lipid and lipoprotein levels between offspring whose mothers received fish oil versus olive oil or no oil during pregnancy, indicating no effect of fish oil supplementation on adolescent lipid profiles.
population_specificity: Pregnant women (third trimester) and their 19-year-old offspring.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with fish oil rich in ω3 fatty acids increases cerebral glucose metabolism in young or elderly adults.
results_summary: The study found no effect of ω3 supplementation on cerebral glucose metabolism in healthy elderly or young adults, though higher plasma triglyceride and insulin levels were associated with lower cerebral glucose metabolism in some regions.
population_specificity: Healthy young (23±5 years old; n=5) and elderly (76±3 years old; n=6) women and men.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of traditional foods, particularly fatty fish, in improving vitamin D status among Arctic Aboriginal populations at high risk of deficiency.
results_summary: The study found that traditional foods like fatty fish are rich sources of vitamin D and should be promoted to address deficiency. Supplementation may also be necessary to ensure adequate vitamin D levels in these populations.
population_specificity: Aboriginal populations living above the Arctic Circle

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the cognitive and mood effects of 12-week dietary supplementation with two types of fish oil (DHA-rich and EPA-rich) in healthy young adults.
results_summary: The study found minimal effects of fish oil supplementation on cognitive performance and mood, with the only notable finding being that EPA-rich fish oil may reduce subjective mental fatigue during high cognitive demand. Overall, the results suggest no significant cognitive enhancement in healthy populations.
population_specificity: 159 healthy young adults aged 18-35 years.
effective_dosage: 1 g/d of fish oil (DHA-rich and EPA-rich).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of re-esterified omega-3 fatty acid triacylglycerols (n3-FA-rTAGs) and ethyl-esters (n3-FA-EEs) on fasting serum lipid levels in dyslipidemic statin-treated participants.
results_summary: The study found that re-esterified omega-3 fatty acids (rTAG) significantly reduced fasting serum triglyceride levels after three and six months compared to baseline, while ethyl-esters (EE) did not. However, there was no significant difference between the two omega-3 forms, though rTAG showed a significant reduction compared to placebo after six months.
population_specificity: 150 dyslipidemic statin-treated participants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of omega-3 long-chain polyunsaturated fatty acids (ω3 LC-PUFA) from fish oil on cardiovascular disease risk factors, including blood pressure, lipid profiles, and glycemic control.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation modestly reduced blood pressure, improved vascular endothelial function, and lowered triglycerides, with minor increases in LDL-cholesterol but beneficial changes in LDL particle size. It showed no adverse interactions with common drug therapies for hypertension, dyslipidemia, and type-2 diabetes.
population_specificity: Untreated and treated hypertensives, individuals with insulin resistance, type-2 diabetes, and metabolic syndrome.
effective_dosage: >3g/d for blood pressure reduction; 5-8 g/d in some studies (though higher doses raised concerns about glycemic control).
interactions: No adverse interactions noted; some synergistic effects with common drug therapies.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether fish oil supplementation reduces the incidence of postsurgical atrial fibrillation (AF) in patients undergoing CABG and valve procedures.
results_summary: Fish oil supplementation did not significantly reduce the incidence of postsurgical AF but was associated with a non-statistically significant delay in AF onset and a significant decrease in intensive care unit stay duration.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing mixed cardiac surgery (CABG and valve procedures).
effective_dosage: 4.6 g/day of long-chain ω-3 fatty acids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether daily supplementation with long-chain n-3 fatty acids during the third trimester of pregnancy affects adiposity in offspring at 19 years of age.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in BMI, waist circumference, or biochemical measures between offspring whose mothers received fish oil versus olive oil during pregnancy. The results indicated no effect of fish-oil supplementation on adolescent adiposity.
population_specificity: Pregnant women in their third trimester and their offspring followed up at 19 years of age.
effective_dosage: 2.7 g long-chain n-3 fatty acids daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review current evidence and trials on the effects of enteral and parenteral glutamine supplementation in multiple trauma patients.
results_summary: Parenteral glutamine supplementation improved survival rates and reduced infectious complications, costs, and hospital stays in critically ill patients, but enteral glutamine supplementation results were inconclusive. Further trials are needed to confirm the best administration method and outcomes.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients, specifically multiple trauma patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if oral glutamine supplementation improved outcomes in children with persistent diarrhea when added to standard treatment.
results_summary: The study found no benefit of glutamine supplementation on persistent diarrhea outcomes, with similar failure rates between the glutamine and control groups. The relative risk was not statistically significant (P = 0.12).
population_specificity: Children aged 2 to 60 months with persistent diarrhea.
effective_dosage: Twice daily glutamine (specific amount not provided).
